text: [Applause]
this is CJ chippers for the New York
Times we went to the Kunar province in
Afghanistan which is in the east near
the border with Pakistan in order to get
a glimpse of the state of the insurgency
in the spring of 2009 two well-known
valleys in in Kunar province are areas
that have seen some of the most
intensive fighting in Afghanistan over
the last several years there the pÃªche
Valley and the Korengal Valley they're
both quite small the corn go valley is
exceptionally small the fight there
takes place and a handful of villages no
more than several hundred houses a
string of farmers fields and sort of a
network of trails that connect them
the ultimate goal would be to get the
Afghan villages to side with the
government and to accept a place in the
government and to allow government
services and authority to come into
these valleys there have been places in
Afghanistan where the Americans have
made headway and the Korengal Valley is
not one of them it's very much a
stalemate you don't have a government
here yet what you have is a fight on
this patrol second Platoon Bravo Company
heads to the nearby village of lani all
to meet with elders and gain traction
and what they hope will become a
counterinsurgency campaign there after
the bomb explodes the Taliban begins an
ambush with small arms fire and
rocket-propelled grenades the Americans
take what cover they can
five American soldiers had walked down
the trail and the insurgents detonated
the bomb under the sixth man by doing it
this way the American Patrol is now
divided one man private first class
Richard to water
has been killed the fourth man killed on
the platoon and nine months here and the
16th man killed in the battalion the two
lieutenants huddle where the river meets
they are exposed but they have a good
view from here they can try to
coordinate the American actions in a way
that will push the insurgents off and
allow the trapped Americans to escape
one thing that's becomes self-evident
over the last few years is that many of
these units have become much more
proficient at their tactics they have a
corps of veteran soldiers veteran NCOs
and officers who have multiple tours in
one war or the other or both and the
unit's now are at the fundamental
tactical level much stronger much more
capable than they were several years ago
they have better equipment
[Applause]
the American officers and NCOs are
making decisions very quickly and very
decisively that can affect the flow of a
battle and if you're in their midst you
can see it happening around you with
terrific speed
the other side suppress the soldiers can
throw smoke grenades to obscure the
withdrawal they don't know at the moment
whether this is the Lal or the end of
the fight maybe the Taliban is waiting
for more they're prepared to keep firing
to cover the withdrawal of the men on
the other side the process of fighting
for the valley against the Americans has
hardened the insurgency these are
experienced fighters and while they have
weaknesses they're not particularly good
shots they're not particularly heavily
equipped they sometimes don't seem to
have a great deal of ammunition well
they have all of these weaknesses they
also have a variety of strengths they
know the local terrain better than the
Americans ever will they're fully a
climatic they know exactly where they
can move without being seen by the
Americans the insurgents also operate a
network of spotters that look down from
the ridges on the American position and
they can see often times when the
patrols are coming or going both sides
and tactical terms act clearly
rationally once the firepower tilts to
the Americans side the Taliban begins to
withdraw have the insurgents been
injured or killed where have they simply
slipped away the Americans don't know as
is often the case
[Applause]
with a larger force here and more
firebases up and down the valley it
might be possible to tilt the balance in
the americans favor but at present the
soldiers here will tell you that they're
at deadlock
